importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Naroditsky won the under-12 World Youth Chess Championship in 2007, marking the beginning of his international recognition as a prodigious talent.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Naroditsky's career spanned from his early achievements in 2007 through his academic and public chess career, culminating in a bachelor's degree in history by 2019.

keyTakeAways: Daniel Naroditsky, an American chess grandmaster, died at the age of 29.
He earned the title of grandmaster before high school graduation and won multiple national and international youth chess championships.
Naroditsky was a prolific educator and commentator, with a strong presence on YouTube and Twitch, reaching nearly half a million subscribers on YouTube and 340,000 followers on Twitch.
He contributed to prominent platforms like Chess Life and the New York Times as a chess columnist and writer.
The Charlotte Chess Center and the International Chess Federation both acknowledged his contributions to the chess community.
A moment of silence was observed at the 2025 US Chess Championship in St. Louis in his honor.
He was described as a beloved educator, mentor, and community pillar, especially for young players and online audiences.
Naroditsky’s family has requested privacy following his death.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Daniel Naroditsky, an American chess grandmaster and educator, died at age 29. Born in the San Francisco Bay Area, he earned grandmaster status before high school and achieved early recognition as the youngest California K-12 champion and under-12 World Youth Chess Champion in 2007. After attending Stanford University, where he earned a history degree in 2019, Naroditsky became a prominent chess commentator and educator through his work with the New York Times, Chess Life, and online platforms. He gained a massive global audience through livestreams on YouTube (nearly 500k subscribers) and Twitch (340k followers), where he made complex chess strategies accessible. The Charlotte Chess Center, the International Chess Federation, and the Saint Louis Chess Club all recognized his contributions. A moment of silence was observed at the 2025 US Chess Championship in his honor. His family has requested privacy.
title: American chess grandmaster Daniel Naroditsky dies at 29
